timeline.summary: On July 06, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity. There were no discrepancies during the morning watch shift. During the day shift, Correctional Assignment 10 South vacated due to staff shortages, and inmate Johnson #50972-054 was moved from KN to ZA. During the evening shift, Correctional Assignment 10-South #2 and SHU #2 vacated due to staff shortages. New inmate Epstein #76318-054 was admitted. No inmates were released or transferred to Special Housing Units. No cells were triple bunked. There were missing reports and equipment inventory forms related to video monitoring, the tool room, safety, training, recreation, the rear gate, roof recreation, floor sallyports, and R&D. Leave utilization included various types of time off, and 27 staff members worked overtime, specifically 197.45 hours of B-2 overtime. The institution’s total population at the start of the morning shift was 789.

On July 06, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity. There were no discrepancies during the morning watch shift. During the day shift, Correctional assignment 10 south vacated due to staff shortages, and inmate Johnson #50972-054 was moved from KN to ZA. The evening watch shift saw Correctional assignment 10-South #2 and SHU #2 vacated due to staff shortages. Inmates were present in outside hospitals, suicide watch, and furloughs. New admissions included Epstein #76318-054. There were no releases or admissions to the Special Housing Unit. There were no triple bunked cells or missing reports. Leave utilized included various types of leave (furlough, annual, sick, etc.). Overtime hours were recorded, primarily B-2 overtime (197.45 hours). Institutional totals at the beginning of the morning shift were: Unit B-A: 28, Unit E-N: 86, Unit E-S: 81, Unit G-N: 79, Unit G-S: 94, Unit H-A: 00, Unit I-N: 86, Unit K-N: 90, Unit K-S: 156, Unit Z-A: 74, Unit Z-B: 05, totaling 789.

On July 06, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity. There were no discrepancies during the morning watch shift. During the day shift, Correctional Assignment 10 South vacated due to staff shortages, and inmate Johnson #50972-054 was moved from KN to ZA. During the evening shift, Correctional Assignment 10-South #2 and SHU #2 vacated due to staff shortages.  New inmate Epstein #76318-054 was admitted. No inmates were released or transferred to special housing units.  There were no cells triple-bunked.  Missing reports and inventory forms were noted across various departments.  Staff leave usage included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and suspension. Overtime hours were recorded, primarily in B-2 overtime. Initial staff numbers at the start of the morning shift totaled 789.

On July 7, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York experienced staffing shortages leading to the vacating of several correctional assignments across all shifts (Morning, Day, and Evening). New inmate self-surrenders and an inmate transfer (Epstein #76318-054) were recorded. There were also issues with inmate occupancy in Special Housing Units (SHU) and missing reports regarding fire and security. Leave utilization included various types of time off, with a total of 223.45 hours worked. Unit occupancy numbers were recorded at 790.

On July 7, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity. Several correctional assignments (internal #2, 10 south #2, SHU #2, SHU #3, SHU #4, and internal #2) were vacated due to staff shortages and new inmate commitments. Inmate Epstein #76318-054 was transferred from EN to ZA. There were no new admissions or releases. Epstein #76318-054 was admitted to the Special Housing Unit. No cells were triple bunked. Leave utilized included various types such as furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and overtime. Overtime hours were recorded, predominantly in B-2 overtime. Institutional totals at the beginning of the morning shift numbered 790, distributed across various units.

On July 07, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York experienced staffing shortages leading to the vacating of several correctional assignments (internal #2, assignments 10 south #2, SHU #2, SHU #3, SHU #4, and ZA). A new inmate, Williams #76319-054, was admitted, and inmate Epstein #76318-054 was transferred from EN to ZA.  Cherry #76218-054 was admitted to Local Hospital with USMS guards. No inmates were released. Epstein #76318-054 was admitted to the Special Housing Unit. No SHU cells were triple-bunked. Leave utilized included various types totaling 18 days. Overtime hours were recorded, primarily B-2 overtime (223.45 hours). Institutional totals at the beginning of the morning watch shift were: Unit B-A: 28, Unit E-N: 85, Unit E-S: 81, Unit G-N: 79, Unit G-S: 94, Unit H-A: 00, Unit I-N: 86, Unit K-N: 90, Unit K-S: 156, Unit Z-A: 76, Unit Z-B: 05, totaling 790.

On July 7, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York reported daily activity. Staff shortages led to the vacation of several correctional assignments (internal #2, SHU #2, #3, #4, and 10-South #2) due to new inmate commitments and staff absences. Inmate Williams #76319-054 self-surrendered and Epstein #76318-054 was transferred from EN to ZA. There were new admissions (Williams) and no releases or admissions to the Special Housing Unit. No cells were triple-bunked. Leave utilization included various types of time off, including furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and overtime. Overtime hours were primarily B-2 (223.45 hours). The institution’s total staff count at the beginning of the morning watch shift was 790.

On July 08, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York reported daily activity. There were no significant incidents during the Morning Watch shift. The Day Watch shift noted a Fire Suppression System inoperative and initiated a fire watch. Staff shortages led to the vacating of Correctional assignments 10-South #2.  I/M Epstein #76318-054 was placed on Psychological Observation. New inmate admissions included Benjamin, Brown, Buchanan, Cabrera, Delacruz, Marshall, Ortiz, Quiroga, Roberson, and releases included Bignon, Delgado, Garcia, Kim, Mendoza, Pena, Reid, Richardson, Rivera, and Zamora.  A staff search was conducted due to missing reports and equipment. Leave utilized included various types such as furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and AWOL. Overtime was recorded for E-1, 60-Q (USM Medical), and other categories. The institution’s total population at the beginning of the morning shift was 790.

On July 9, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported the following: *   A fire suppression system was inoperative during the morning watch shift. *   No significant incidents occurred during the day watch shift. *   Correctional assignment SHU #2 was vacated due to staff shortages during the evening watch shift. *   Inmate I/M Epstein #76318-054 was on psychiatric observation with a companion. *   There were no new admissions, releases, or special housing unit (SHU) occupancy issues beyond triple bunking. *   Several staff searches were conducted regarding missing reports and equipment inventories. *   Staff utilized various types of leave (furlough, annual, sick, etc.) and overtime hours (E-1, 60-Q, B-2, etc.). *   The institution had a total of 790 inmates at the beginning of the morning watch shift, distributed across various units.

On July 09, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported the following: *   A fire suppression system was inoperative during the morning watch shift. *   No significant incidents were reported during the day watch shift. *   Correctional assignment SHU #2 was vacated due to staff shortages during the evening watch shift. *   New inmate admissions included Anghel, Green, Hudson, Kenyatta, and Rai. *   Several inmates were released, including Atkins, Burnett, McCollum, and Tran. *   There were no cells triple bunked in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). *   A staff search was underway for missing fire and security reports and an equipment inventory form. *   35 staff members worked overtime totaling 230.15 hours. *   Beginning institutional totals were 790.

On July 10, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity. There were no significant incidents during the Morning Watch shift. The Day Watch shift experienced a shortage of staff leading to the vacated Correctional assignments. The Evening Watch shift resulted in inmate Epstein (#76813-054) being placed on the Special Housing Unit (SHU) due to a Psychiatric Obsession. Inmates Epstein (#76318-054) and his companion were on Psychiatric Obsession within the hospital. There were new admissions to MCC, including Epstein (#76813-054) from Psychiatric Obsession. Staff searches were conducted in Tool Room, Sallyport 2, and Sallyport 3. There were missing equipment inventories from Sallyport 2, Sallyport 3, and Roof Recreation. Leave usage included various types, including furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and AWOL. Overtime was recorded, including 60-Q overtime (USM Medical) and B-2 overtime. The institution’s total inmate count at the beginning of the Morning Watch shift was 792.

On July 12, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York reported daily activity. A hole was discovered on the institution’s exterior, leading to an Immediate Use of Force involving inmates in various assignments due to staff shortages. An inmate was observed on psychiatric observation, and another was under suicide watch. Several housing units were investigated for SIS investigations and failures to return on time. Staff searches were conducted across multiple areas, including lobbies, Sallyports, and facilities shops, resulting in missing equipment inventory. Leave usage included furloughs, annual leave, sick leave, and overtime hours. The institution’s population at the beginning of the morning shift totaled 801 inmates across various units.

On July 13, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) reported daily activity to the Warden and relevant staff. The Operations Lieutenant documented several shifts (Morning, Day, and Evening) noting staff shortages resulting in the vacating of SHU #2 and SHU #3. Inmates were observed under psychiatric observation with companions, and there were new admissions and releases. No cells in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) were triple-bunked. Staff leave included furloughs, sick leave, and a single AWOL incident. Overtime hours totaled 238, and the total number of staff on hand was 30. Initial institutional totals at 12:00 AM on July 13th showed various unit occupancies totaling 797.

On July 14, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) reported daily activity. There was no unusual activity during the morning watch shift. The day watch shift involved correctional assignments, a new inmate admission to BA, and vacated assignments due to staff shortages. The evening watch shift also had a staff shortage. Inmates were noted on psych observation, and there were no triple-bunked cells in the SHU. Leave usage included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and a suspension. Overtime hours were recorded, totaling 241.00 hours across various categories. The institution’s total population at the beginning of the morning watch shift was 797.

On July 14, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York received a daily activity report from the Operations Lieutenant. There was no unusual activity reported during the morning watch shift. The day watch shift noted correctional assignments, a shortage of staff leading to the vacating of units 10-South #2 and SHU #4, and a new inmate committment to BA. The evening watch shift also reported a staff shortage resulting in the vacancy of 10-South #2.  Inmate status reports included individuals on psychiatric observation, new admissions, and releases.  No cells in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) were triple-bunked. Leave usage included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and a suspension. Overtime hours were recorded for various staff classifications. Institutional totals at the beginning of the morning watch shift were provided, detailing the number of inmates in specific units.

On July 14, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York reported daily activity. Lieutenant biontchStua reported no unusual activity during the morning watch shift. Correctional assignments were made to 10-South #2 and SHU #4 due to staff shortages, and one inmate was transferred to BA. The evening watch shift saw 10-South #2 vacated due to staff shortages. Inmates were observed on psychiatric observation with companions. New admissions and releases occurred, as did admissions to the Special Housing Unit. Leave utilization included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and suspension. Overtime hours totaled 241.00. Unit occupancy was recorded as 797.

On July 18, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York reported several operational issues and staff activity.  A Control Center Door malfunctioned during the morning watch shift, and two correctional assignments (SHU #2 and 11-South) were vacated due to staff shortages during the evening watch shift.  Inmates were on suicide watch at a local hospice, and new admissions and releases were noted.  There were missing reports and inventories.  Staff utilized various types of leave (furlough, annual, sick, etc.) and worked overtime hours, totaling 323.30 across multiple overtime categories. The institution’s total cell count at the beginning of the morning watch was 784.

*   **Reporting Officer:** Lieutenant of M/W Operations. *   **Reported Issues:** *   An I/M unit was flooded. *   The SHU #2 was vacated due to staff shortage. *   Inmates were under psychiatric observation, suicide watch, or hospice care. *   **Missing Reports/Inventory:** Several missing reports and inventory forms were noted across various departments (SIS Office, Visiting Room, Central Tool Room, Roof Recreation). *   **Leave Utilization:** Detailed records of leave types (furlough, annual, sick, overtime, etc.) were logged, including specific hours worked. *   **Cell Occupancy:** No cells were triple-bunked. *   **Population Count:** The total inmate population at the beginning of the morning watch was 786. *   **Unit Breakdown:** Specific inmate counts for several units (B-A, E-N, E-S, G-N, etc.) were listed.

On July 19, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York reported several operational issues. The morning watch shift noted a malfunctioning Control Center Door requiring manual operation. The day shift reported a shortage of staff within the Special Housing Unit (SHU) #3 and a code violation (Codes #111/113/224). The evening shift reported vacant areas including SHU #4, Visit #1, and Lobby i2 due to staff shortages. There were no cells in the SHU triple bunked. Several areas were missing equipment including the Visiting Room, Rear Gate, SIS Office, Central Tool Room, and CMC/R&D/Mailroom. Staff leave included various types of time off (furlough, annual leave, sick leave, suspension, AWOL, etc.) and overtime hours (60-Q overtime for USM Medical, B-2 overtime). The institution’s total population at the beginning of the morning shift was 787.

On July 20, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity. Several correctional assignments (10-South #2 and SHU #3) were vacated due to staff shortages during the evening watch shift. Unit 11 South remained on modified operations. There were no new admissions or releases. No cells were triple bunked. Several missing reports and equipment inventory forms were noted, including those for the Visiting Room, Rear Gate, SIS Office, Central Tool Room, CMC/R&D/Mailroom, and Sally Officers. Seven staff members utilized leave (furlough, annual, sick, COP, AWOL). 28 staff members worked overtime, totaling 222.00 hours. Institutional totals at the beginning of the morning watch shift (July 20, 2019, 12:00 AM) indicated 780 inmates across various units.

On July 21, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York received a daily activity report from the Operations Lieutenant. Several staffing shortages were reported across shifts (Mornin, Da, and Evening Watch) due to absences. Correctional assignments 10-South #2 were vacated, and assignments in SHU #3 and 10 South #2 were also vacant. There were no new admissions, releases, or special housing unit occupancy issues. Several reports were missing, including fire and security reports and equipment inventories. Leave utilization included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, AWOL, and LWOP. Staffing consisted of 28 individuals, with overtime hours totaling 222.00. Unit counts at the beginning of the morning shift totaled 780.

On July 21, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity. Several units (11 South, 10-South #2, SHU #3, SHU #4, and 11 South #2) were vacated due to staff shortages during the evening watch shift. Inmates were present in outside hospitals, suicide watch, and furlough. There were no new admissions, releases, or admissions to the Special Housing Unit. No missing reports or equipment were noted. Staff utilized various types of leave, including furlough, annual, sick, and AWOL. Overtime was utilized, totaling 190.20 hours. The beginning of the morning watch shift reported 780 inmates across various units.

On July 22, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) reported the following: *   A threat of a stabbing by gang members was reported by the Control Center regarding the 11-South housing unit. *   A fire alarm and sprinkler system were inoperable, triggering a fire watch. *   Inmates were temporarily relocated to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) due to staff shortages. *   A pressure pump system failure resulted in a continued fire watch. *   There were no cells triple-bunked. *   Several areas lacked missing fire and security reports and equipment inventories. *   Staff utilized overtime hours (E-1, 60-Q, B-2, O9D, XXX, 87S) and various leave types (furlough, annual, sick, suspension, etc.). *   The institution’s total inmate count at 12:00 AM was 776, distributed across various units.

On July 23, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York reported various operational issues, including a malfunctioning control panel for doors, inmate suicide watch for I/M Epstein, and staffing shortages leading to vacant correctional assignments. Inmates were present in outside hospitals, undergoing suicide watch, or on furlough. There were new and released inmate admissions and adjustments to housing units, particularly within the Special Housing Unit (SHU). Several areas experienced missing fire and security reports or equipment inventories. Overtime hours were recorded, and the beginning of the morning watch shift indicated a total population of 776 inmates across multiple units.

On July 23, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported several operational issues during the three watch shifts. Control panels for ES/GS Main Door/Fire Exit doors and the Inner Gate were inoperative during the morning shift. A suicide watch was initiated on inmate I/M Epstein. Staff shortages resulted in vacant correctional assignments in 10-South and SHU 14. Missing equipment reports were submitted from various locations including Sallyports, the Central Tool Room, and the Chapel. Leave utilization included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and suspension. Overtime hours were recorded for E-1 staff. Institutional totals at the beginning of the morning shift were: Unit B-A: 26, Unit E-N: 88, Unit E-S: 86, Unit G-N: 76, Unit G-S: 91, Unit H-A: 00, Unit I-N: 89, Unit K-N: 92, Unit K-S: 139, Unit Z-A: 74, Unit Z-B: 05, totaling 776.

On July 23, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York experienced operational issues including a malfunctioning control panel for doors, inmate suicide watches initiated (I/M Epstein), and fire watch activities across multiple units. Staff shortages led to adjustments in correctional assignments within the 9-South and SHU 14 units. Several inmates were in outside hospital care or under suicide watch. There were new and released inmate admissions and a lack of completed fire and security reports from several locations. Overtime hours were recorded, totaling 166.30 hours. The institution’s population at the beginning of the morning shift was 776.

On July 23, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York reported several operational issues during the daily activity report. Control panels for ES/GS Main Door/Fire Exit doors and the Inner Gate were inoperative during the morning watch shift.  A Suicide Watch was placed on inmate Epstein #76318-054. Fire Watches were ongoing during the day and evening shifts due to staff shortages in Correctional Assignments SHU #4 and 10-South #2. Several inmates were in outside hospitals, under suicide watch, or on furlough. New and released inmates were recorded, and there were no current triple-bunked SHU cells.  Missing reports and equipment were noted across multiple locations within the facility. Overtime hours were recorded for E-1 staff. The institution’s total inmate population at the beginning of the morning shift was 776.

On July 25, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York reported daily activity. Staff expressed exhaustion due to overtime. There were inquiries regarding inmate I/M Epstein’s potential suicide attempt. Inmates were placed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) for possession of cellular telephones. Several inmates were admitted and released, including Deleon, Guillen, Kaba, Aguilar, Lamarco, Murray, and Williams. A shortage of staff resulted in unassigned correctional assignments. There were missing reports and inventory forms. Leave utilization included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and overtime hours. The institution’s population at the start of the morning shift was 774.

On July 26, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York reported daily activity. Staff expressed exhaustion from overtime, and there was a fire watch in progress during multiple shifts. Inmates I/M Epstein and Kaba were investigated for potential suicide attempts and possession of cellular telephones, respectively. Several inmates were moved to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) due to these issues. Staff shortages led to unassigned correctional assignments.  Inmates Aguilar, Lamarco, Murray, and Williams were released, while Deleon, Guillen (three instances), and Kaba were admitted to the SHU.  There were no cells triple bunked. A staff search was conducted across multiple areas of the facility, including Sallyports, offices, and security areas. Leave utilization included furloughs, sick leave, and overtime hours. Unit counts at the beginning of the morning shift totaled 774.

On July 26, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity. Fire watch was ongoing across multiple shifts. There were incidents involving media outside the institution regarding inmate Epstein (#76318-054) and inmate Brown (#70786-050) being placed in Special Housing Unit (SHU) Pend SIS. New inmate admissions included Hilario (#87048-054) and Hossain (#87049-054), while Epps (#86975-054), Sears (#28569-057), and Southwell (#77179-054) were released. Inmate Brown (#70786-050) was admitted to SHU. There were no triple-bunked cells. Missing reports and equipment inventories were noted from various departments. Leave utilization included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and overtime hours. Staffing levels were reported at 24 with 186.00 overtime hours worked. Initial unit counts at 12:00 AM were 770.

On July 27, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported ongoing fire watch shifts across all morning, day, and evening watch shifts. Correctional assignments were frequently unassigned due to staff shortages. Inmates were under observation within the hospital, suicide watch, or furlough. There were no new admissions, releases, or special housing unit (SHU) over-bunking. Leave utilized included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and a single instance of Combat Operations Pay (COP).  Thirty-three staff members worked overtime, totaling 234.00 hours of B-2 overtime. The institution’s total population at the beginning of the morning shift was 767.

On July 27, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity, primarily focusing on fire watch incidents across multiple shifts. Staff shortages resulted in unassigned correctional officer assignments. Inmates were monitored in various observation and restriction settings (Psych Observation, Suicide Watch, SHU). There were no new or released admissions or adoptions to the Special Housing Unit. Leave utilization included various types of time off, and overtime hours were recorded for multiple staff categories. Cell occupancy was detailed, with a total of 767 cells occupied across various units.

On July 27, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity. Fire watches were ongoing during all shifts. Correctional assignments were frequently short due to staffing shortages, particularly in SHU units and sanitation. There were no new admissions or releases. No cells were triple-bunked.  Leave utilized included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and a one-year LWOP. Overtime hours were recorded, primarily in B-2 overtime (234 hours). The beginning of the morning watch shift on July 27, 2019, showed a total of 767 inmates across various units.

On July 27, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity across three shifts (Morning, Day, and Evening). Fire watches were ongoing across all shifts. Staff shortages led to unassigned correctional officer assignments, primarily in SHU units. There were no new admissions, releases, or special housing unit admissions. No cells were triple bunked, and there were no missing reports. Leave utilization included various types of time off, and overtime hours were recorded, including B-2 overtime (234 hours) and 60-Q overtime (USM Medical). The beginning of the morning watch shift showed a total of 767 inmates across various units.

On July 28, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity through a memorandum to the Warden and relevant staff. Key events included: *   Multiple fire watch assignments due to staff shortages. *   An inmate transferred to special housing due to a fight on unit 7 South. *   An inmate transferred to the hospital for treatment and subsequently to special housing. *   Inmate Epstein was on psych observation with a companion. *   No new admissions or releases. *   No cells in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) were triple-bunked. *   No missing reports or equipment were noted. *   23 staff members worked 165.15 hours in E-1 overtime. *   2 staff members worked 16 hours in E-1 comp time. *   Staff totals at the beginning of the morning watch were 767.

On July 28, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity. Fire watches were ongoing during all shifts. An inmate was transferred to special housing during the morning watch, and an unwitnessed fight occurred on unit 7 South during the evening watch. Several inmates were in outside hospitals, under suicide watch, or on furlough. There were no new admissions or releases. No cells in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) were triple bunked. No missing reports or equipment were noted. Leave utilization included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and a suspension. Overtime hours were recorded, primarily for medical and special assignments. The institution’s total inmate count at the beginning of the morning shift was 767.

On July 30, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) reported the following: *   A fire panel in the Control Center was inoperative during the Morning Watch Shift. *   Inmate Epstein (#76318-054) was removed from psychiatric observation and housed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) #3, 10-South #2, due to staff shortages. *   SHU #4 remained unassigned due to staff shortages. *   There were no triple-bunked cells in the SHU. *   Several departments (SIS Office, Video Monitoring, Chapel, Education, Recreation, Safety, 2 Sallyport, Central Tool Room, 3 Sallyport, Roof Recreation) had missing equipment inventory forms. *   Staff leave included various types of time off (furlough, annual leave, sick leave, overtime, suspension, etc.) and 210 hours of overtime were worked. *   The institution’s total population at the beginning of the morning shift was 767.

On July 30, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported the following: *   A fire panel was inoperative during the morning watch shift. *   Inmate Epstein (#76318-054) was removed from psychological observation and housed in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) #3 due to staff shortages. *   SHU #4 remained unassigned due to staff shortages. *   There were no triple-bunked cells in the SHU. *   Several departments (SIS, Video Monitoring, Chapel, Education, Recreation, Safety, 2 & 3 Sallyports, Central Tool Room) were missing reports. *   A missing equipment inventory form was also noted. *   Staff utilized various types of leave including furloughs, annual leave, sick leave, overtime, and suspension. *   A total of 767 inmates were present at the beginning of the morning watch shift, broken down by unit.

On August 01, 2019, the Operations Lieutenant reported several issues during the daily activity reporting period. Unsecured food slots due to hinge malfunctions and inmate tampering were a recurring problem across multiple units.  Several inmates were placed on the Special Housing Unit (SHU) Pend SIS due to various reasons including I/M placements and staff shortages impacting correctional assignments.  Inmate status changes included hospitalizations, psychiatric observation, and furloughs. New admissions to Metropolitan Correctional Center New York (MCC NY) included inmates placed on the SHU with pending SIS classifications. Release information, missing equipment inventory, and staff leave/overtime details were also documented, including 26 staff members working a total of 189.30 hours.  Cell occupancy was noted, with no SHU units triple-bunked, and a total of 763 inmates housed across various units at 12:00 AM on August 01, 2019.

This memorandum, dated August 02, 2019, is a daily activity report from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. It details operational issues including unsecured food slots, inmate placements in Special Housing Units (SHU) due to staff shortages, new and released inmate admissions, and staff leave and overtime. Specific inmate incidents include placement on SIS, Code assignments, and movement to/from the Special Unit. It also records missing equipment, inmate locations (hospital, suicide watch, furlough), and institutional cell counts at the beginning of the morning watch shift.

On August 03, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York reported daily activity. There was no unusual activity during the morning watch shift. Staff shortages led to unassigned correctional assignments in shifts (South #2, SHU #4, SHU #3), due to a shortage of staff. Inmates were under suicide watch (Benjamin #86463-054), and a new inmate (Melendez #85799-054) was admitted for a hospital return. No releases or admissions to the Special Housing Unit occurred. No missing equipment or reports were noted. Leave utilized included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and overtime. Overtime hours were recorded, with a total of 238 hours. Cell occupancy was reported with 761 total cells. Unit occupancy counts were provided at the beginning of the morning watch shift.

On August 03, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity. There was no unusual activity during the morning watch shift. Shortages of staff led to unassigned correctional assignments in shifts (10 South #2, SHU #4, lobby #2, SHU #3, and SHU #2). Inmates were on suicide watch, and there were no new admissions or releases. No cells were triple bunked. No missing reports or equipment were noted. Leave utilized included furloughs, sick leave, and overtime. Total staff was 30. Institutional totals at the beginning of the morning watch shift were 761.

On August 03, 2019, a Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York reported daily activity for August 02, 2019, as communicated by an Operations Lieutenant.  Inmates were assigned to various housing units (SHU #2, 4, etc.) with several experiencing placement on the Special Housing Unit (Pend SIS). New inmate admissions and releases were recorded.  Several inmates were under observation (hospital, suicide watch, furlough).  There were no triple-bunked SHU cells.  Missing equipment inventory forms were noted, along with staff leave utilization and overtime hours.  The institution’s inmate population at the beginning of the morning watch shift was recorded as 766.

On August 04, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity. Staff shortages resulted in unassigned correctional assignments during the morning and day watch shifts. No unusual activity was reported during the evening watch shift. Inmates were on suicide watch, and new admissions and releases were recorded. Leave utilization included furloughs, annual leave, sick leave, and overtime hours. Staffing numbers varied across different overtime categories. The institution’s total inmate population at the beginning of the morning watch was 762.

On August 05, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York reported the following: *   Shortages of staff led to the vacating of several correctional assignments across all watch shifts (Morning, Day, Evening). *   Inmates were placed on Suicide Watch and Special Housing Unit (SHU) Pend SIS. *   New admissions and releases occurred, with one inmate on Suicide Watch accompanied by a companion. *   No cells in the SHU were triple-bunked. *   A missing equipment inventory was initiated, covering various areas of the facility. *   Staff leave included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and suspension. *   Overtime hours were recorded, including standard overtime, medical overtime, and treaty transport overtime. *   The institution’s total population at the beginning of the morning watch shift was 762.

On August 06, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity. A 1/M inmate, 485426-054 and 479455-054, was placed on Special Housing Unit (SHU) #4 due to possession of a weapon. Staff shortages resulted in the vacancy of Phone Monitor, 3 Sally Officer, and SHU #10 South #2. Inmates #85978-054 was on Suicide Watch, and #86463-054 was awaiting a bed space in the SHU. New admissions included #87077-054, #87078-054, and #76326-054, while #79455-054 was admitted to the SHU. Staff search, Chapel, SIS Office, Central Tool Room, Sallyport 2, Staff Search, Roof Recreation were missing. Overtime hours were recorded, totaling 206.30 for E-1 overtime and 8 for comp time. Institutional totals at the beginning of the morning watch were 759.

On August 9, 2019, a daily activity report was generated for the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The report details inmate movements, staffing shortages (particularly sanitation and control center fire panel issues), new admissions and releases, and leave utilization. Specific inmate incidents included placements in SHU, dry cells, and suicide watch. There were also missing equipment inventory forms and a fire/security report deficit. Overtime hours were recorded, primarily for Treaty Transfers. Initial cell counts at the beginning of the morning watch shift totaled 759.

On August 10, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported daily activity issues including staff shortages leading to the vacation of a correctional assignment and an unresponsive inmate requiring outside hospital treatment. There were multiple inmates on suicide watch. No new admissions, releases, or bed space issues in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) were reported. Leave utilization included furlough, sick leave, and overtime hours. Staff numbers totaled 34. Initial cell counts at the beginning of the morning watch shift were recorded as 759 across various units.

On August 10, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported several operational issues and staff absences. A shortage of staff led to the vacation of correctional assignments, specifically in 10 South #2 and unit B-2. An inmate, I/M Epstein #76318-054, was found unresponsive and transported to a hospital for treatment. Three inmates were on suicide watch. There were no new admissions, releases, or additions to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) that created triple bunked conditions. No missing fire or security reports or equipment inventories were noted. Staff leave utilization included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and a small amount of compensatory time. Overtime hours were recorded, primarily for 87S OVERTIME (Treaty Trans), totaling 263 hours. The institution’s total inmate count at the beginning of the morning watch shift was 759.

On August 10, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York reported several operational issues and inmate status updates. A correctional assignment (Sanitation) was vacated due to staff shortages, and the Control Center Fire Panel remained inoperative. An inmate, I/M Epstein, was escorted to the hospital for treatment. Several inmates were placed on Suicide Watch with inmate companions. There were no new admissions or releases. No cells in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) were triple-bunked. No missing equipment reports were filed. Leave utilized included various types, with significant sick leave taken. Overtime hours were recorded, including 3 staff members working 87S overtime. Initial cell counts at the beginning of the morning watch shift totaled 759.

On August 14, 2019, the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York reported several issues including a fire panel inoperative, staff shortages leading to placement in Special Housing Units, and missing reports/inventory forms across multiple departments. Leave utilization included furlough, annual leave, sick leave, overtime, and AWOL time. The beginning morning watch shift population totaled 758 inmates across various units.  Specifically, 23 staff members worked 163.00 hours in E-1 overtime, and 3 staff members worked 24 hours in COMPTIME.

An email exchange occurred between an individual (“From”) and an unknown recipient (“To”) on August 15, 2019. The sender expresses concern about a significant staff shortage and officers working extended shifts (up to five days consecutively). The recipient inquires about the sender’s well-being. An attached file named “TEXT.htm” was included.

On August 16, 2019, a Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York Operations Lieutenant reported staff shortages across multiple shifts, leading to the vacating of several correctional assignments. An inmate was placed in Special Housing Unit (SHU) due to a serious assault on staff. Inmates were noted to be on psychiatric observation, suicide watch, and awaiting bed space. There were new admissions from the SHU (from HA) and one inmate was released. Leave utilization included various types of time off, including furlough, annual leave, sick leave, and overtime. Institutional totals at the beginning of the morning watch shift were recorded, showing a total of 757 inmates.
